head.supplied: Melbourne, 5th May 1887 ¶ Sir ¶ ¶ In conformity with your circular No. 1586 ¶ I have the honor to submit herewith estimates of expenditure for my department during 1887/8. ¶ ¶ I may be permitted to...

div.p: J87/4173, unit 298, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof.
MS written by Georg Luehmann and signed by M. Melbourne, 5th May 1887

In conformity with your circular No. 1586
See T. Wilson to M, 2 May 1887. I have the honor to submit herewith estimates of expenditure for my department during 1887/8.

I may be permitted to observe that, although no direct revenue is received through my department, yet a considerable amount is paid annually in to the consolidated revenue by the Govt. Printer for the sale of books published by me.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I have the honor to be

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
No pensions and no gratutities under Acts 160 and 773 in Govt. Botanist's Department.
MS annotation in an unknown hand: 'note to Mr Luehmann 6/5'. On 12 May 1887 Luehmann sent a telegram to J. Killen, position: 'No Revenue in the Dept of Govt Botanist for 1887'. He sent another telegram on 19 May: 'No Pensions nor Gratuities in Govt Botanists Dept. for 1887.8 [i.e.:1887/8] as stated in letter.'

The Honorable the Chief Secretary.
The file contains a newspaper cutting from the Argus, 14 October 1887, reporting the parliamentary discussion of the 'vote of £2,748 for the Government botanist', which was passed. M's valuable contribution to the colony was extolled and the need for 'a proper botanical museum' was endorsed.
ESTIMATES of Expenditure for the Year ending 30th June, 1888.

cell.p:
800
Each of these amounts are marked with a note by Luehmann: 'Salary above maximum'.

Clerk
MS annotation by Luehmann: 'With quarters (one room) valued at £18 per annum.'
